title: Regulates the use of informants by the prosecuting attorney and law enforcement personnel
summary: Regulates the use of informants by the prosecuting attorney and law enforcement personnel; requires law enforcement personnel to submit an annual report to the department of state with statistical information relating to their use of informants.

BILL NUMBER:S1229

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the election law, in relation
to campaign finance enforcement

PURPOSE:
This is an omnibus bill designed to enhance enforcement of
New York State's campaign finance law by authorizing the state
board of elections to impose civil penalties for violations of
that law, creating a mechanism for notifying corporations of the
$5,000 aggregate annual limit on their political contributions,
and establishing the village clerk's authority to enforce the
campaign finance filing requirements imposed upon village candidates.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
A. Civil Enforcement

This bill adds to the enforcement powers of the state board
of elections, enumerated in section 3-104 of the election law, by
allowing the board to proceed administratively when it determines
that a violation of article 14 has occurred. The board is
authorized to assess a civil penalty, as set forth in section
14-126 of the election law, following the hearing.

Section 14-126 of the election law is amended to increase
the civil penalty provision from a maximum of one hundred dollars
to ten thousand dollars and to make clear that it is applicable
to all violations of article 14, rather than just
failures to
file. The power of the State Board and other boards to proceed
judicially for civil penalties under section 3-104 is amended to
conform with the change in section 14-126.

A new section 3-105 is created in the election law to set
forth the procedures to be followed in conducting an
administrative proceeding, issuing a determination, and assessing
a civil penalty. Except as specifically provided, the hearing
shall be conducted pursuant to article 3 of the state
administrative procedure act. The board is required to randomly
select hearing officers from an active list of at least six
qualified attorneys. Such hearing officers must meet the
qualifications established by the board pursuant to regulations
designed to ensure objectivity and independence, and are to be
paid as independent contractors on a per diem basis
at a rate fixed by the board.

Following the hearing, the hearing officer shall submit a
report to the board and, after reviewing that report, the Board
shall make a determination as to whether a violation has occurred

and, when appropriate, shall impose a civil penalty. The board
shall promulgate regulations setting forth factors to be
considered in setting such penalty amounts.

B. Enforcement by Village Clerk

Sections two, six and seven of the bill extend to the
village clerk the powers to enforce the requirements of article
14 of the election law which powers are currently possessed by
the state board and local boards of elections. Section six amends
subdivision five of section 3-104 to empower the village clerk to
institute a civil proceeding for civil penalties against a
village candidate or committee which violates the campaign
finance requirements set forth in article 14. Section eight of
the bill amends subdivision one of section 14-126 to include
village clerks in the list of petitioners who can seek civil
penalties in a judicial proceeding. Section seven amends section
16-114 of the bill to extend to village clerks the power to institute
a judicial proceeding seeking an order that a candidate
or committee required to file with the village make that filing.

C. Enforcement of Corporate Contribution Limits

Section five of the bill adds a new subdivision four to
section 14-118 to affirmatively state that treasurers of
political committees are obligated to ensure that they do not
accept more than $5,000 from any corporate contributor. The
bill specifically requires that excess corporate contributions be
returned within 10 days of receipt. Moreover, the bill requires
treasurers who receive contributions of $1,000 or more from a
corporation to notify that corporation of the statutory limit of
$5,000 per year.

D. Miscellaneous Provisions

Section four of the bill amends subdivision two of section
14-116 to clarify that the corporate contribution limit of $5,000
per calendar year does not apply to contributions for the
purpose of promoting or defeating a ballot issue.

JUSTIFICATION:

A. Civil Enforcement

The state board of elections investigates approximately 50
matters each year, with about 30 to 40 percent of those matters
relating to violations of the campaign finance law, as set forth
in article 14 of the election law. In many instances, the board
concludes that while a violation has occurred, criminal
prosecution is not warranted because of the inability to

establish criminal intent, the existence of extenuating
circumstances, or the insignificance of the offense.

Under current law, when such a conclusion is reached, the
board often has no choice but to refer it to the district
attorney regardless of merit or drop the matter altogether. While
the former solution places an unnecessary burden on prosecutors
and threatens a minor violator with a disproportionate sanction,
the latter solution sends a message of indifference to candidates
and their committees and eliminates the chance that similar
violations will be deterred in the future. By providing the board
with an additional, alternative enforcement tool -- the power to
impose civil penalties following an administrative hearing --
compliance with campaign finance requirements should
substantially improved.

Further, by making clear that these penalties are available
for all article 14 violations, an impediment to
effective
enforcement by the board will be removed -- and by establishing
an administrative review procedure, a more appropriate forum to
litigate these matters will be provided. However, such reforms
would prove meaningless without an increase in the amount of the
maximum civil penalty allowed by law. Given the cost of litigating
these matters in any forum and the nominal deterrent
effect of $100 civil penalty, it would be difficult to justify
civil enforcement absent a change in the penalty amount.
Consequently, to insure effective enforcement of New York State's
campaign finance law, this bill increases the maximum civil
penalty amount the state board may assess to $10,000.

B. Enforcement by Village Clerk

Existing law provides for state board and local
board-initiated lawsuits to enforce the filing requirements of article
14 of the election law. The practice has been for the state board
to institute proceedings in those instances in which the filing
should have been made at its office and to refer to local boards
of elections violations involving local filings. In addition,
there are numerous instances brought to the attention of the
state board each year where the violation involved a village
election; however, the law makes no reference to lawsuits
initiated by village clerks. This provision corrects that
oversight, and would therefore enhance enforcement at the village
level.

C. Enforcement of Corporate Contribution Limits

One of the most difficult compliance issues this board
encounters relates to the $5,000 annual limit on political
contributions by corporations. The board currently uses a manual
system to tabulate corporate contributions and its

computerization plans will increase the board's detection
capacity. However, once they are identified as exceeding the
limit, many corporations claim they were unaware of the limit and
that sanctioning them would be unfair. The bill recognizes that
notification to politically active corporations of the limit will
improve compliance and, if ignored, will facilitate the board's
enforcement efforts. Those most able to reach politically active
corporations are obviously the treasurers of the political
committees to which the corporations contribute. Because it is
reasonable to expect that significant contributions ($1,000 or
more) will be acknowledged in writing anyway, this requirement
will pose no extra burden on treasurers.

D. Miscellaneous Provisions

Existing law which prohibits corporations from contributing
more than $5,000 in a calendar year makes no distinction
between contributions in support or opposition of candidates and
contributions to promote the success or defeat of a ballot issue.
The United States Supreme Court, in First National Bank of
Boston
v. Bellotti, 435 U.S. 716 (1978) ruled that there could be no
limits on the latter. This bill conforms New York law to the
Bellotti case.

FISCAL IMPACT:
This bill will have no fiscal impact on the state this
year.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
The first April after which the bill shall have become law,
except that the state board of elections shall immediately
promulgate rules and regulations to implement adjudicatory
hearings.
